Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 09:02PM - edited Feb 27, 2012 09:13PM by YramAL I wish I had seen this when I was going thru rads 2 years ago. It would have helped me understand more what was going on with my body. I have no complaints about my radiation oncologist, as some do. He was(and is) a very kind, compassionate person. I had severe "burns" under my breast towards the end of treatment, and not once did he dismiss my symptoms and discomfort. His nursing staff was wonderful as well. As far as those hydrogel pads? Lifesavers! Here is the brand I used. http://www.sterlingmedical.com/EXT/SMS/SterlingProducts.nsf/catalog/3811 I got them from the rad onc's office. I would sort of wedge one under my breast and use a soft bra to keep it in place all day. I don't know how I would have gotten through the last couple of weeks of treatment without them. Mary

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 11:33AM YramAL wrote: The way it was explained to me was that the Oncotype test addresses the risk of the cancer metastisizing to other parts of my body, such as the lungs, liver, bones, etc. My score was 11, so I chose not to do chemo. Radiation is for reducing the risk of a local recurrence-in other words, it helps get rid of any unseen cancer cells in my breast that were not totally removed in my surgery. It helps to keep the cancer from coming back in that breast. My doctor showed my the CT scan of the area that is being treated, and the range of the radiation. In my case, it totally misses my heart and barely, barely skims a small portion of my lung. I started my radiation 9 weeks after my lumpectomy. My radiation oncologist said the ideal time is 6-8 weeks after surgery, but I was waiting for the results of my Oncotype test. If I had had to have chemo, I would have done that first.

Click on the forum name and it will give you an option to start and title your own thread. I wish you peace of mind and hope that this new thing in your other breast really is nothing. Mary

Posts.Title: Looks Like I'll Have To Take My Wife Out Of The Country Sepahunt22 CathyB

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 05:58PM YramAL wrote: I work at an elementary school, and we have had some students show up wearing the "I <heart> Boobies" bracelets. I asked our principal what the school's policy was about something like this, and he told me that if they don't cause a distraction to instruction, the students can wear them. If, on the other hand, they disrupt learning, we can ban them.  I find that the students who wear them the most, and have them taken away the most for inappropriate behavior, are 11- and 12-year old boys. There is absolutely no breast cancer awareness in chanting, "I love boobies! I love boobies!" over and over again in response to one of the boys wearing a bracelet. I took the bracelet away, and the boy said, "But that's for breast cancer awareness!" I said nothing-the students have no idea I'm a breast cancer patient. My husband asked me why I didn't say anything to the boys about my breast cancer, and I told him that I didn't think they would care one bit-it was all about being able to say "boobies". Mary

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 12:55AM YramAL wrote: I have insurance and my biopsy was about 3 weeks after my mammo/ultrasound. I agree with all the posters here who say that it is probably a matter of scheduling. Try to do some special things for yourself in the meantime. Mary
Posts.Title: Is it because I'm young or because I have no insurance. karamelspice karamelspice

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2012 06:34PM YramAL wrote: I had a similar experience, but after my presurgery MRI. My surgeon came in right before my surgery and sort of offhandedly remarked,"You have a mass on your left kidney, it could be a cyst or something you've had since birth. We'll check it out with ultrasound." Here I was, definitely with breast cancer, and now I had this to worry about! I had an upper abdominal ultrasound and it turns out I have what is called an "accesory spleen"-an extra spleen. Who knew? Nothing to worry about and not all that uncommon. I guess my point is, even if your letter isn't some sort of mistake, it could be other things besides cancer that they are looking for. Mary

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 07:43PM YramAL wrote: Suepen- You'll know the area is starting to heal when you see patches of white under there(instead of angry red!). As my rad onc explained it, those white areas are the new skin growing-he called them "islands"-and before you know it, they start to expand, and pretty soon they meet, and voila! You are healed!  Mary

I figured if I was going to put my faith in the oncotype test, I should go with a doctor that believes in it as well. Got an oncotype score of 11, so...no chemo for me. Mary

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 05:36PM YramAL wrote: Suepen-I had the exact same thing happen to me as happened to you. The skin under my rather large breast broke down during the 5th week of my 6 1/2 weeks of treatment. My rads nurse gave me some gel pads called Carradress and they saved my life. I sort of wedged them in under my breast, over the sore area, and kept them in place with my bra. Once I was switched to my boost treatments, that area got a break and healed in about a week. I'm 7 weeks out from rads now, and the area that was broken down is still discolored, but it is totally healed. Believe me, when I was going through it, I thought it was never going to heal.  Ask for some gel burn pad dressings. They're about 3' by 3' and they were a lifesaver for me. Mary

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 03:15PM YramAL wrote: I had 4 removed-no lymphedema so far. I was told that all "lit up" with the tracer dye used to locate the sentinel node, and that's why 4 were taken instead of 1. Mary
Posts.Title: Totally confused about sentinel node biopsy results LtotheK LtotheK

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 12:30PM YramAL wrote: Laurie- I also had a breast MRI after my diagnosis of IDC back in December. I was told ahead of time that an MRI may show up areas of concern that later turn out to be nothing because the MRI is so sensitive. I did not have any further breast issues turn up, but my MRI showed a possible mass on my kidney. Talk about scary!!! I had a followup ultrasound on my kidney and it turns out I have an accessory spleen-a totally benign condition.  My breast MRI did show my axilary nodes. They appeared to be disease free on my MRI, and in fact, they were, as shown by my pathology report following my surgery. Best of luck. Keep breathing.......I know you are going through a scary time right now, but I promise you it will get better once you know exactly what you are dealing with and can make a plan. Mary

Posts.Title: Follow up with surgeon for 5 years? Why? Halah Mantra

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 12:03AM YramAL wrote: Susan-if nothing else, you need to find an oncologist that you feel comfortable with. Whatever course of treatment you decide to take-and it IS your decision, made with info from your doctors-you will be seeing this person for a long time to come.   The oncologist I went to for my first opinion had much of the same dismissive attitude towards the Oncotype test. She made pretty much the same comment your doctor made about if the cancer comes back you won't survive. I didn't like that she dismissed my questions so easily.  I went to another oncologist for a 2nd opinion, and he was very open to the idea of the Oncotype test, and I'm grateful that he was, because my score came back at 11, so no chemo for me. I also like him because he is a very personable guy who lets me ask as many questions as I want to ask, and I never feel rushed or unimportant. I definitely went by my "gut" feeling, accompanied by good, solid medical info, of course.  Mary

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 10:22PM - edited Aug 6, 2012 10:23PM by YramAL I don't mean to scare you, but you need to know that a mastectomy does not guarantee that you won't ever have breast cancer again. My sister-in-law had a double mastectomy, and had a recurrence in her mastectomy scar.  I'm not telling you not to have a mastectomy-just know it doesn't mean you never have to worry again. I wish for you pain free surgery, treatment and recovery. You are way too young to get this-but you don't need me to tell you that! I was 49, and my oncologist calls ME young! Mary
Posts.Title: 23 Years Old And Very Scared justegan justegan

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 11:06PM YramAL wrote: WeeSee- My mom always told me how painful her mammograms were, so that when I went to have my first one, I was really scared that it would hurt. It wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be-sure, it wasn't anything I would call fun-but it was mostly just a feeling of pressure when they squeezed my breast between the paddles. I usually take tylenol or ibuprofen before going for my mammogram. One of my breasts-the lumpectomy/rads one- is extra tender, but to me, a little pain is worth it. My cancer was caught on my annual mammogram. I was 49, and had been having mammos for 9 years. Never felt a lump, nothing. Yet there it was.   Best of luck to you. I've been following your struggles on the other thread. I sure hope you get some answers. Mary

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 01:49AM YramAL wrote: Kim- I was told that ideal time for rads is about 6 weeks post surgery. I started my rads 10 weeks after surgery because I was waiting for the results of my Oncotype DX test to find out if I needed chemo. The test was not ordered at the time of my surgery, but a few weeks later by the onco I decided to go with. I ended up not getting chemo because of my low Onco score, but my rads were delayed for a few weeks. My onco said that in the big scheme of things, the wait is not significant, and I'm choosing to trust him and move forward. I'm also taking Tamoxifen and have been for about 12 weeks with no major side effects. I'm so sorry your rads are interfering with your family fun this summer. Hopefully your doctor will OK the wait until after your reunion but I don't think I'd go in August. Maybe your family could plan a vacation later? My husband and I went to Disneyland when I finished my rads and had a great time!  Mary

Posts.Title: PET Results CoolBreeze ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 08:56PM YramAL wrote: I actually found out by email from the nurse navigator at the breast center, but that was because I just kept emailing her with questions like, "Can the radiologist be fairly certain of a diagnosis based on the ultrasound?" and "Does the fact that the radiologist left a marker in at the site of my biopsy mean that she thinks it's probably cancer?" and other questions I can't even remember-I was just so stressed out. She emailed me back and said something like, "I think you already know the results of your biopsy-please give me a call..." I work at an elementary school and can't take calls during the day unless it's an emergency, but I went right to my principal's office and told her, "I think I have breast cancer. I need to call my nurse." My principal started to cry and told me,"You'll get through this. Whatever you need, I'm 100% behind you." I called the nurse navigator, and sure enough, she told me I had IDC. I think I had already mentally prepared myself for the news, so it wasn't really all that shocking to me. Wow-this post brought back a lot of memories. In a post-traumatic stress kind of way. I don't think I've thought about that day for quite some time. Mary
Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 12:03AM YramAL wrote: I'm not an attorney but the part about not even taking Tamoxifen bothers me. I have several friends with varying stages and types of ER+/PR+ breast cancer, and every single one of them has or is taking Tamoxifen, even the one that had DCIS that was treated with a mastectomy. I don't think you're sue-happy. Mary
Posts.Title: Attorney in the house? lisa34lisa lisa34lisa

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:22PM YramAL wrote: Ash- I second Irr4993 in saying waiting for the results of the biopsy was worse than the biopsy itself, and when I found out I had cancer, it was almost a relief-very strange, but true. I think when I knew what I had, I could start planning what to do next. I drove myself to and from my biopsy, which was pretty much as everyone else has described. I only told my husband and one of my friends that I was having the biopsy because I didn't want everyone else to worry too much. Unfortunately, I turned out to have cancer. But you know what? I'm OK.  The odds are in your favor that your lump will be benign-I hope that's so.   Mary
Posts.Title: new member and very stressed ashisonfire ashisonfire

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 05:53AM YramAL wrote: I had the Oncotype test back in January of this year. When my doctor submitted the test, Genomic Health called me and let me know that if my insurance denied my claim, they would appeal it up to 3 times on my behalf. If that failed, they would see if I qualified for their financial assistance program(the income limits were quite high, IMO, as I recall), and if all else failed they would take payments on a schedule that I could afford. All this was moot in the long run since my insurance covered the test. Covering the test actually saved my insurance company boat loads of money in the long run because I probably would have had chemo, almost solely based on the fact that my tumor was 1.5 cm. I received a low Oncotype score of 11, so decided not to do chemo. I understand that chemo runs thousands and thousands of dollars.  It's too bad you can't call Genomic Health today(Saturday) because I really do think they will ease your mind quite a bit.  Mary
